The Autoimmune Paleo Cookbook 

A Recipe Book For the Autoimmune Protocol

free from gluten, grains, beans, soy, dairy, eggs, nuts, seeds, and nightshades

After releasing The Autoimmune Paleo Cookbook as an ebook in April, I had an overwhelming response from those who wanted me to release a version in print. Many of you recovering from autoimmune disease, chronic illness or having severe food allergies have found the book to be helpful in your journey and requested that I come out with a print version. I am so happy to announce that it is happening!

It has taken me awhile to figure out how to produce a print version of this book because I wanted it to be good. While the ebook was something I designed and edited on my own, while I was still healing, I now have the time, energy and headspace to devote to making this an even more inspiring and beautiful in print. 

I am not simply looking to print the ebook - what I aim to create is a high-quality, hardback cookbook, clearly and beautifully laid out, and including photos for every recipe contained within. I am elaborating and expanding the resources in the beginning in the book, so it is more of a stand-alone guide for those who may be new to the autoimmune protocol. 

I am seeking funding in order to complete the design phase of the book - the money I raise from pre-orders will go to paying a professional photographer, designer, and editor to make sure the book is well-executed. I am self-publishing this book, so I can make it exactly the resource I want it to be - but the downside is that I will need all of the funds upfront for the production.

Included in the book: 

  • About the autoimmune protocol - including lists of what to eat and avoid 
  • How to go about reintroducing foods
  • Two 4-week meal plans
  • Shopping lists
  • Shopping guide
  • Tips and tricks 
  • Healing foods and staples like bone broth and fermented foods 

110 recipes, fully compliant for the strictest phase of the autoimmune protocol - no grains, beans, dairy, eggs, nuts, seeds, or nightshades. 

Recipes include easy, weeknight meals that even those with little cooking experience can make - soups, stews, salads, and easy staples to have on hand. The book also contains some more elaborate preparations, for those seeking something more special. My aim is to have recipes for a variety of situations - from someone with little time or energy to cook, to those who love food and want to create gourmet meals that are also stay within the bounds of their food allergies. Many of the recipes are family-friendly and suitable for holiday gatherings. I also offer replacements for common foods like milk, noodles, tomato sauce, BBQ sauce, cheesecake, and pie - all which don't lend themselves to be easily adaptable to the autoimmune protocol.

For those of you who already have the ebook, this is what is new:

  • A full-page photo of every recipe in the book
  • 10 new recipes 
  • Expanded and updated details on the autoimmune protocol
  • A section about how to reintroduce foods 
  • Professional formatting and design with most recipes having their own page
  • High quality printing/binding so that the book lies flat while in use

Please help me reach my goal so that I can provide this resource to the autoimmune community! Your pre-order means everything to the possibility of being able to finish this project and get it out into the world.

Prologue

 

This story is about a man who bound, raped and tortured my child for years before she disclosed her abuse to me in April of 1999. My daughter gradually began to reveal more and more details of her abuse including describing extremely graphic and disturbing details of murder. Over time I came to realize that her abuse was NOT about Pedophilia, but about Sadism and a child victim who fulfilled his Sadistic needs in between his kills.

My story documents the charm, cunning and manipulative nature of a psychopath who's organization, skill and evolution has allowed him to get away with his crimes including escaping prosecution for what he did to my child. My story shares the obscure measures that this self proclaimed "Genius", took to surround himself with easy prey and to carry out his crimes against them without detection. It would be years before I could gather the strength to resume my fight for justice for my child and begin to piece together this spectacular story that links this deviant to the Zodiac Killer who continued to claim victims in British Columbia, Canada for the past 40 years.

 

 

My Story can be Followed at:

 

 www.zodiackillernorth.blogspot.com

 

 

My daughter Jennifer, age 6, during some

of the worst years of her abuse.  

 

The Story

 

Henning Lagies, the man whom I had met in my foster home at the age of 16 was a good friend of my foster father and was in the home nearly everyday.  I grew to know him over the two years that I had lived there, and after moving out of the foster home Henning would become like a father to me and eventually like a grandfather to my child over the 16 year period of our relationship.  Little did I know that this man was a predator and in hindsight I realized that he strategically placed himself in close proximity of where he could find victims who would be easy to prey on.  The fact that I was a foster child with no family or support systems allowed him to gain my trust and loyalty which he would use to keep me close to him and to eventually gain access to my child after I became a mother.  It was years that I spent time with this man who I also worked with at DND, that allowed him the ability to mould my mind, to take his word as gospel and to trust him more than anyone in the world.  I would never have imagined in my worst nightmares that this man whom I had loved and trusted without any hesitation, would be the man who would cast the ultimate betrayal upon me and my child and would subject my child to sadistic sexual abuse and expose my child to graphic and gory murder scenes.  Whether my child was actually present at these murders, or Henning implanted these acts of violence into her head, this story will share the most astonishing details that will reveal the fantasies of a depraved man whom I absolutely believe is a killer.

I still have audio of some of the murder stories that my child relayed to me and drawings of skinned female genitalia that she claimed she saw her abuser eat.  Henning was supposed to be a vegatarian and he often made a bit of a spectacle in public about being a vegetarian, which I now realize was just part of his act, a common theme that I would later come to realize was his way of creating an illusion as to who he really was.  My child also drew a picture of a "Machine", that she saw Henning put bodies into, which accurately portrayed a woodchipper, and she also drew a "Tool" that was actually a pair of plyers, that she claims Henning used to pull out a lady's teeth.  I tried to share these details with the RCMP, but the investigating officer wouldn't listen and the charges against Henning were eventually dropped and my child and I were left teetering in the aftermath of this man's crimes without any resolve.  The Vancouver Police Department did get involved regarding my child's murder stories and the Vancouver missing women, and set my child up with a play therapist which they paid for for 9 months.  Although the VPD believed my child was sexually abused they had no jurisdiction and there was never anything tangible for them to go on regarding the murders.  Eventually I began to unravel from the stresss.  My child ended up in foster care and I ended up on disability for several years, but gradually, through counselling, I was able to start digging myself out of the dark place that I had lived for so many years.

In 2007 I recognized the handwriting from Robert Graysmith's movie "Zodiac", as being the exact same style as Henning's writing.  I hadn't really known much about Zodiac at the time, other than it was a story we talked about as kids about some guy killing couples and the fact that he was never caught.  It wasn't until watching the movie in 2007 that I connected the strange coincidence about the handwriting appearing to match a man whom I had now believed was a killer since my daughter's disclosures of her sadistic abuse and depictions of murder in 1999.  I did a little research and I pulled what samples of Henning's handwriting I had to compare with Zodiac letters that I found on the internet, and I was amazed to see how closely Henning's writing resembled Zodiac's.  Not only that, but after reading numerous letters that were written by Zodiac, I was struck by the fact that Zodiac's linguistics also appeared to link Henning to being the Zodiac Killer.  Two things that really stood out for me was how Zodiac always used the word "Shall", as did Henning, and how Zodiac wrote in a letter to the editor "Happy Christmass", amongst a multitude of other phrasing and idealisms.  One year Henning had given me a card that said "Happy Christmass", spelled just like that.  When I told him that is now how you spell Christmas, he just shrugged.  Now here is a man with genius IQ and he doesn't know how to spell Christmas?  Not likely, but at the time I didn't know much about Zodiac so I never made the connection.  There would be much more that I would later discover, but not until years later when I accidentally stumbled across more details that possibly linked Henning to being the Zodiac Killer, as well as the BC Serial Killer who had been claiming victims in British Columbia for 40 years since Zodiac went out of site in the United States.

In January of 2010  I began conducting research on our missing women from the Vancouver, Eastside as well as along Highway 16 now dubbed the "Highway of Tears", trying to find clues as to the murder stories that my child had relayed to me.  It was then that I accidentally stumbled across more details that points the suspect in the BC killings as possibly being the Zodiac Killer, simply killing equal distances North and South of the Canada/US Border and also in areas on both sides of the border where he had family living.  My research shows timelines that match to Zodiac as well as when killings began in BC and times the suspect had opportunity to kill and was in the vincinity of women who vanished in BC amongst a multitude of other circumstantial evidence.  Much of this information is documented on my blog, but there is much more than I could ever say in a blog and it will all be revealed in my book.

  

Although the RCMP dismissed what happend to my child, subsequent reports from Children's Hospital would support that she was sexually abused.   The reports also show that her depictions of murder, cannibalism and exposure to extreme violence were documented and were not diagnosed as manipulation, or psychosis.

 

First Children's Hospital Report (Emergency Ward Admission): 

http://www.blogger.com/blogger.g?blogID=908155290998243248#editor/target=post;postID=2023702395599358892

Second Children's Hospital Report (1 month Residential Psychiatric Assessment):  http://zodiackillernorth.blogspot.com/2011/04/residential-care-of-child-confirms.html

It contains a brief 1.5 minute excerpt and a 22 minute exceprt of audio from my then 8 year old daughter describing some of the graphic murder scenes she claims to have been at (edited largely to remove graphic content). I share this not for shock value, but to bring awareness and understanding as to the horrific events that my child suffered at the hands of her abuser, and to show that this man is dangerous and to support my belief that he is a killer.

http://zodiackillernorth.blogspot.com/2011/10/audio-released-child-describes-graphic.html

1.5 minute excerpt shows a picture of my daughter 5 weeks before she disclosed her abuse.

Her abuser is reflected in the mirror behind her.

 

Zodiac Killer

 

In the sections below there are references taken from three separate sites on the internet that discuss "Zodiac's Profile", the profile of an "Organized Serial Killer", and "What Makes a Psychopath?"  Many have questioned my theory on Henning being the Zodiac Killer, because they don't feel that the BC killings match the Zodiac Killings.  My book will reveal how Henning matches most of the traits described in the various sections below, how serial killers evolve, and how psychopaths can and do change victim type including changing from children to adults and vice versa.  When the data from the expert Forensic community is parallelled with characteristics of Henning and the many erie details of his existance, it will become clear how this man does indeed fit the profile of the Zodiac Killer who evolved into the BC Serial Killer and a Cannibal.

  

Henning Lagies compared to original composite of Zodiac with parted hair and added beard

 

 

Age Progressed Composite of Zodiac              

 

 

 

Part hair, remove glasses, and add beard

 

http://www.forartist.com/forensic/composite/zodiaccase.htm

    

Zodiac Killer Profile

By Gregg McCrary

http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/notorious/zodiac_profile/5.html

 

The killer constantly changed his method of operating and openly admitted that murder was sport for him. The attacks occurred at dusk or after dark, on weekends, often around holidays, with different weapons and apparently with no motive save violence itself. Clearly, the killer wanted credit for them and he turned most of his rage against females.

Possible motives were to prove his superiority, get attention, control the investigation, create a terroristic climate, and relive the crimes via media reports. Going after couples, which he did three times, could indicate that he was envious or jealous because he did not (or could not) have that kind of relationship. It might also have been to show that he was not afraid to confront a male, although the fact that he targeted three couples when he could have only shot lone females or lone males indicates resentment about relationships.

He liked to ambush his victims, yet for him none of these incidents were high risk crimes. While they were out in the open, they were not risky. Even when he set himself up for a potential risk, by being interviewed by phone, for example, he usually withdrew. Yet it's possible that he believed he was taking a risk, so he could congratulate himself when he did not get caught. Maybe he viewed these crimes as proof of his skill in stealth. He might have fantasized about himself being more daring than he actually was. By all witness accounts, he appeared to be late twenties to early thirties, heavyset, strong, and aggressive. It wouldn't be surprising that his fantasies of being a skilled "hunter" grew from an immature and insecure mind.

Nevertheless, the man who called himself the Zodiac was organized, intelligent and meticulous. If we take the reference to the Zodiac seriously, we find several symbols in his initial cryptogram that look like the symbol for Taurus the bull, which could identify his approximate birth date. He obviously liked astrology and might have viewed himself as fated by the stars. Those close to him would probably have heard him engage in knowledgeable discussions about astrological symbols and meanings.

Among the most engaging aspects of the crimes for him was to be able to taunt the authorities from a superior perspective and to watch the police make fools of themselves. This often indicates a person who feels uncertain about his intelligence, so to reassure himself, he plays games with others. The Zodiac needed to think he was smarter than even the best detectives, and he probably exaggerated the risks he took in order to affirm his smug sense of superiority. People who knew him would have been familiar with his arrogance, as well as his shortcomings and insecurity.

He used a lot of diversionary tactics, such as making threats that turned out not to be true, or posing cryptic mysteries. This is a form of what's called "duping delight." He's excited by duping others. The puzzles he presented probably meant nothing, but this man enjoyed knowing that a whole city full of people, as well as a number of law enforcement agencies, were at work on whatever code or clue he sent. That would have given him a thrill, knowing that the resolutions were merely dead-ends, and yet people would keep trying to find out what they meant. The closer they thought they were to identifying him, the more it would have amused him.

He enjoyed the control he exerted because he was in charge; he was running the investigation, more or less, as though he was the supervisor. He might have had pretensions of being a police officer, but for some reason been barred from this profession. This way, with these threats, he got to order them about. When he moved from the Vallejo area into San Francisco for his murders, he acquired a greater venue for control, along with the ability to spread the terror and feel more powerful. For him, it was all about that. He exerted control over his victims, and he did the same with anyone who was concerned about becoming a random victim.

He especially enjoyed controlling the newspapers and the police agencies of a town the size of San Francisco. He liked knowing they got into tiffs over territory and investigative squabbles. To his mind, that was more evidence of how stupid they were, and each day that went by without them catching him reinforced this opinion and sense of superiority. Every communication he sent fueled that fire.

 
Organized Homicide

http://psychautopsy.weebly.com/organized-vs-disorganized.html

Organized offenders are psychopathic and antisocial, irrational but sane. They are indifferent to fellow humans, irresponsible, and self-centered. They are manipulative, deliberative, and full of guile but outwardly amiable as long as it suits his objective. In other words, this type of offender could truly be a pillar of the community, the patron saint of child or spousal abuse prevention, and the neighborhood's most willing handyman. All the while, he is also the bogeyman who stalks his community's women, tortures them, and snuffs out their last breath. He is equally convincing in both roles and this is why the news reports always show the community astonishment in phrases like, "He was always such a nice guy."

They are cunning and emotionless, which is how they can play both sides of the coin. When you have nothing emotional to invest in anyone, giving everyone exactly what they want takes nothing from you, but it can give you an advantage when you are trying to keep people from suspecting you are a compulsive murderer. This offender is extroverted, articulate, and highly narcissistic. He takes great care with his physical health and appearance. He will dress himself neatly whether in business or casual attire.

There will always be a specific stressor in the offender's life that precipitates the beginning of his murderous career. These can be related to finances, employment, a marriage, or any close relationship. While there are events that will trigger the leap to murder, the fantasy is what fuels and builds up the desire to commit the crime. Offenders of this type will spend years, a decade or more, constructing their fantasy world. They use their crimes to hone these fantasies and improve upon them in order to heighten their level of self-gratification.

This offender will perpetrate very deliberative crimes, thoroughly calculated and planned. Premeditation of these crimes will also typically include extensive stalking. He preys mostly on strangers so that he cannot be linked to their victims in any way. He will hunt far from work or home, but in an area he has surveilled and become intimately familiar with. The abduction and abuse of the victim will be perpetrated with as much precision and calculation as the predator has put into planning his clear escape. An organized sexual homicide will have multiple scenes: the location of initial contact or assault, the scene of death, and the body disposal site. This offender is socially adept and may con or persuade his victims into going with him willingly. He may pose as an authority figure, using a uniform that will disarm his victims such as that of a police officer.

Victimology for an organized sexual homicide suggests a female or adolescent male. The victim will be single, employed, and live alone. The offender's risk for this type of crime is higher if committed outdoors or during the day. The victim of this crime is not known to the offender, but is chosen because she meets criteria specific to the killer's psychological construct. In multiple, linked homicides, the similarities in appearance of the victims will be obvious. For example, all of Ted Bundy's victims (except the last one) looked just like his ex-fiancee.

This offender plans his murders, spends time targeting his victims, and displays control over the scene. He is methodical and orderly throughout all phases of the crime. The murders themselves are slow and sadistic for an experienced killer who is comfortable with his level of control over all factors. This type of offender is so in control of his surroundings that he can adapt to obstacles that occur during the commission of the crime in an outwardly calm manner. For example, the Zodiac killer was able to provide a dummy description of a dummy suspect when he came face to face with the police who were looking for him minutes after he'd shot a cab driver. Ed Kemper drove through a security gate at a college campus with two dying women in the car without raising any suspicion from the guards. These predators engage in staging to aid them in evading detection. The scene may be altered to appear careless or disorganized on purpose as a way to throw off the investigation. Secondary criminal activity may be staged to disguise the sexual homicide as some other type of murder.

He takes care not to leave fingerprints, semen, or spent cartridges and shells. They make an effort to erase all prints and other potential evidence. Sometimes these perpetrators will scrub the victim down with bleach, along with the bathroom and kitchen, to destroy any trace he may have left. Some have been known to go to the extreme of removing all of their body hair and mutilating the tips of their fingers to avoid mishaps or carelessness at the scene. Weapons are brought to the scene by the perpetrator and leave the scene with him. He will have a "kit" consisting of various items like tape, chains, ropes, or chemicals. Restraints reflect a methodical approach, providing order for the perpetrator prior to, during, and after the crime. The scene will appear controlled and planned out. All finger- and footprints will be removed. Regardless of the ridiculous notions spouted off on television or in movies, these predators DO NOT want to be caught. EVER. They put so much effort into assuring they will outsmart the police because they all want to follow in the footsteps of Zodiac and Saucy Jack.

This offender takes trophies to commemorate the success of his endeavor. They also serve as proof of his skill and control. These items will be used to help the perpetrator relive the fantasy he has acted out. He will conceal or dispose of the body in a location that is familiar to him, but not connected to the area where he lives or works. He will return to surveill the scenes and may inject himself into the investigation by being overly cooperative with law enforcement. Gary Ridgway, the Green River Killer, returned to the dump sites to have sex with the bodies of his victims over and over, until maggots invaded the body. This behavior serves a dual purpose: it keeps him apprised of the progress of the investigation while affording him the opportunity to relive the crime where it happened.

 

Organized Killers

Edmund Kemper, John Wayne Gacy, Ted Bundy (pre-Florida), Bob Berdella, Kenneth Bianchi and Angelo Buono, Gerard John Schaefer, John Joubert, Monte Rissell, David Meierhofer, John Brennan Crutchley

 

What Makes a Psychopath?

 

Excerpts from a discussion by Canadian Forensic Psychologist, Dr. Stephen Porter, UBC.

http://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/health/new-health/conditions/addiction/mental-health/what-makes-a-psychopath/article1770811/

  

Comment From GuestGuest: ] how long have you been studying psychopaths, and has your views changed since you first began your study.

Dr. Stephen Porter:

I started studying psychopaths when I was working in a federal prison for my internship about twelve years ago. I thought I was having success providing weekly therapy to a psychopathic pedophile. However, his diary got confiscated after eleven months of therapy, and it turned out his fantasies were getting more and more sadistic and he wrote that he planned to murder children upon release. Not exactly a therapy success story! I started to research both the violent behaviour of psychopaths and their incredible ability to deceive and manipulate others. My views have changed over that time in the sense that I now believe that psychopaths are extremely rational and know the difference between right and wrong. Earlier, I felt that psychopaths were impulsive and that somehow their bizarre behaviour was beyond their choice. Our research has challenged that idea.

Comment From FredFred: ] What signs would you expect to see from a close contact which may indicate pschopathic tendencies?

Dr. Stephen Porter:

I'm not sure if by "close contact" you mean a family member or acquaintance/work colleague. But either way, typically the person will come across as highly likeable and charming, even charismatic. However, this charm is superficial in the sense that it is all part of an acting job, intended to manipulate the other person. In other words, the individual's behaviour will ultimately contradict the friendly, charming mask. You will see a pattern of persistent lying and deception (from a young age) including false promises, a "gift of gab", callous behaviour, including taking advantage of and conning others, a sense of superiority, stepping on others to get ahead, promiscuous sexual behaviour, and an inability to form anything more than superficial bonds with friends or partners. Often, such individuals are described in a Jekyll and Hyde way, such as "he was so likeable and friendly, a real class clown but then I got involved with him and found out the truth too late."

Comment From Elizabeth: ] As psychopaths know right from wrong, what causes them to commit violent crimes, and what justifications do they give for their behaviour?  

Dr. Stephen Porter:

Great question and one we have been researching for some time. Psychopaths in my view do know right from wrong in the "cognitive" or rational sense, and even do as well on moral-reasoning tasks in the lab setting as the rest of us. A better question might be why don't most people NOT act on their immoral or even violent impulses. All humans have sexual, violent, and antisocial thoughts and impulses that they choose not to act upon because of our "conscience". We have empathy for others and we know we could not live with ourselves if we acted on the dark thought. Psychopaths don't have to worry about a conscience to stop them from doing violent crimes. Research suggests that some of their main motivations include calculated revenge, thrill-seeking and sex, pure greed, and do intimidate and gain power. Many of the violent psychopaths we have studied were inspired purely by getting a thrill. For example, our research shows that the vast majority of sex offenders who cross the line from children to adults or vice versa are psychopaths. When asked about this pattern, one fellow I assessed told me he simply got bored with one victim type and then would move to another type.

 

Geography

 

In my theory I hypothesise how if Henning is the Zodiac Killer that he did not live in the San Francisco area, but traveled from the Vancouver, BC area to San Francisco where he had family.  My theory is that should Henning be the Zodiac Killer, that this was his beginning as a killer.  I would suspect that earlier murders such as Cheri Jo Bates was indeed Henning and I have documented some circumstantial evidence pointing Henning to being her killer as well.  I believe that Henning would have gone through great lengths in order to go undetected, thus traveling the approximate 1,000 miles from Vancouver, BC to San Francisco which allowed him to test the waters in an area where nobody would ever suspect that he would be the killer, and he did so in an area where he would have an alibi by saying he was in town to visit with his family should anyone have seen him.  If we look at the location of the killings in British Columbia, we will see this same pattern of a killer who travelled approximately 1,000 miles along Highways 5, 16 and 97 which is now known as the "Highway of Tears", and has been the location of where dozens of women have disappeared or been found murdered over the past 40 years.  The other parallel linking Zodiac to the BC Serial Killer shows how many of the BC killings again took place in an area where Henning had family living in the 108 Mile Ranch area along the Cariboo Highway (Hwy. 97).  Eerily the approximate location of the home Henning co-owned with his father there (secondary to his Vancouver residence), resembles the location of the Lake Herman Killings near San Francisco, California.

 

Map that shows distances that killings took place on both sides of the Canada/US border in both the Zodiac and BC murders.  The suspect Henning Lagies lives right in the middle of these killing grounds.

 

Map that documents the distance from San Francisco, CA to Vancouver, BC shows that the drive is possible and could account for why the Zodiac murders took place on weekends when it was possible for Henning to drive to and from San Francisco during  these time periods.

 

Map that documents the distance from the Vancouver, BC area to Prince Rupert, BC where killings and disappearances have taken place along this entire stretch of highway over a 40 year period.  This shows how the BC serial killer traveled approximately the same distance up Highway of Tears in British Columbia to kill, as the suspect Henning Lagies may have traveled to San Francisco in the Zodiac Killings.

 

Another coincidence is that Henning lives only 2.6 miles from the Pickton Pig Farm where Robert Pickton tortured and murdered women. It is thought that Pickton had an accomplice.... coincidental or linked? Regardless, Pickton proves that this type of crime does happen and the RCMP should have taken seriously the crimes committed against my child and the possibility that this man is a viable suspect re our missing women. I have repeatedly tried to notify the RCMP, media and missing persons organizations over the past two years about this man in regards to what he did to my child and the fact that he is a dangerous man who should be considered a suspect in the BC killings..... media and others are interested until they actually relay my story to the RCMP who obviously do all they can to downplay my story. Typical of what happend in the Robert Pickton case.

 

Location of suspect's residence in Port Coquitlam, BC (Greater Vancouver area)

 

The DNA of 33 women was found on Robert Picton's farm, but dozens of women are still unaccounted for.

 

Another home that Henning co-owned with his father in 108 Mile Ranch along a section of the Cariboo Highway now dubbed "The Highway of Tears".  Henning co-owned the home sometime from the early to mid 70's and took over ownership in the mid 90's.  Map shows how bodies began to circle an area around his home during that time.

 

The Impact

The Story
 
Henning Lagies, the man whom I had met in my foster home at the age of 16 was a good friend of my foster father and was in the home nearly everyday.  I grew to know him over the two years that I had lived there, and after moving out of the foster home Henning would become like a father to me and eventually like a grandfather to my child over the 16 year period of our relationship.  Little did I know that this man was a predator and in hindsight I realized that he strategically placed himself in close proximity of where he could find victims who would be easy to prey on.  The fact that I was a foster child with no family or support systems allowed him to gain my trust and loyalty which he would use to keep me close to him and to eventually gain access to my child after I became a mother.  It was years that I spent time with this man who I also worked with at DND, that allowed him the ability to mould my mind, to take his word as gospel and to trust him more than anyone in the world.  I would never have imagined in my worst nightmares that this man whom I had loved and trusted without any hesitation, would be the man who would cast the ultimate betrayal upon me and my child and would subject my child to sadistic sexual abuse and expose my child to graphic and gory murder scenes.  Whether my child was actually present at these murders, or Henning implanted these acts of violence into her head, this story will share the most astonishing details that will reveal the fantasies of a depraved man whom I absolutely believe is a killer.
I still have audio of some of the murder stories that my child relayed to me and drawings of skinned female genitalia that she claimed she saw her abuser eat.  Henning was supposed to be a vegatarian and he often made a bit of a spectacle in public about being a vegetarian, which I now realize was just part of his act, a common theme that I would later come to realize was his way of creating an illusion as to who he really was.  My child also drew a picture of a "Machine", that she saw Henning put bodies into, which accurately portrayed a woodchipper, and she also drew a "Tool" that was actually a pair of plyers, that she claims Henning used to pull out a lady's teeth.  I tried to share these details with the RCMP, but the investigating officer wouldn't listen and the charges against Henning were eventually dropped and my child and I were left teetering in the aftermath of this man's crimes without any resolve.  The Vancouver Police Department did get involved regarding my child's murder stories and the Vancouver missing women, and set my child up with a play therapist which they paid for for 9 months.  Although the VPD believed my child was sexually abused they had no jurisdiction and there was never anything tangible for them to go on regarding the murders.  Eventually I began to unravel from the stresss.  My child ended up in foster care and I ended up on disability for several years, but gradually, through counselling, I was able to start digging myself out of the dark place that I had lived for so many years.
In 2007 I recognized the handwriting from Robert Graysmith's movie "Zodiac", as being the exact same style as Henning's writing.  I hadn't really known much about Zodiac at the time, other than it was a story we talked about as kids about some guy killing couples and the fact that he was never caught.  It wasn't until watching the movie in 2007 that I connected the strange coincidence about the handwriting appearing to match a man whom I had now believed was a killer since my daughter's disclosures of her sadistic abuse and depictions of murder in 1999.  I did a little research and I pulled what samples of Henning's handwriting I had to compare with Zodiac letters that I found on the internet, and I was amazed to see how closely Henning's writing resembled Zodiac's.  Not only that, but after reading numerous letters that were written by Zodiac, I was struck by the fact that Zodiac's linguistics also appeared to link Henning to being the Zodiac Killer.  Two things that really stood out for me was how Zodiac always used the word "Shall", as did Henning, and how Zodiac wrote in a letter to the editor "Happy Christmass", amongst a multitude of other phrasing and idealisms.  One year Henning had given me a card that said "Happy Christmass", spelled just like that.  When I told him that is now how you spell Christmas, he just shrugged.  Now here is a man with genius IQ and he doesn't know how to spell Christmas?  Not likely, but at the time I didn't know much about Zodiac so I never made the connection.  There would be much more that I would later discover, but not until years later when I accidentally stumbled across more details that possibly linked Henning to being the Zodiac Killer, as well as the BC Serial Killer who had been claiming victims in British Columbia for 40 years since Zodiac went out of site in the United States.
In January of 2010  I began conducting research on our missing women from the Vancouver, Eastside as well as along Highway 16 now dubbed the "Highway of Tears", trying to find clues as to the murder stories that my child had relayed to me.  It was then that I accidentally stumbled across more details that points the suspect in the BC killings as possibly being the Zodiac Killer, simply killing equal distances North and South of the Canada/US Border and also in areas on both sides of the border where he had family living.  My research shows timelines that match to Zodiac as well as when killings began in BC and times the suspect had opportunity to kill and was in the vincinity of women who vanished in BC amongst a multitude of other circumstantial evidence.  Much of this information is documented on my blog, but there is much more than I could ever say in a blog and it will all be revealed in my book.

Zodiac Killer Profile
By Gregg McCrary
http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/notorious/zodiac_profile/5.html

 
The killer constantly changed his method of operating and openly admitted that murder was sport for him. The attacks occurred at dusk or after dark, on weekends, often around holidays, with different weapons and apparently with no motive save violence itself. Clearly, the killer wanted credit for them and he turned most of his rage against females.
Possible motives were to prove his superiority, get attention, control the investigation, create a terroristic climate, and relive the crimes via media reports. Going after couples, which he did three times, could indicate that he was envious or jealous because he did not (or could not) have that kind of relationship. It might also have been to show that he was not afraid to confront a male, although the fact that he targeted three couples when he could have only shot lone females or lone males indicates resentment about relationships.
He liked to ambush his victims, yet for him none of these incidents were high risk crimes. While they were out in the open, they were not risky. Even when he set himself up for a potential risk, by being interviewed by phone, for example, he usually withdrew. Yet it's possible that he believed he was taking a risk, so he could congratulate himself when he did not get caught. Maybe he viewed these crimes as proof of his skill in stealth. He might have fantasized about himself being more daring than he actually was. By all witness accounts, he appeared to be late twenties to early thirties, heavyset, strong, and aggressive. It wouldn't be surprising that his fantasies of being a skilled "hunter" grew from an immature and insecure mind.
Nevertheless, the man who called himself the Zodiac was organized, intelligent and meticulous. If we take the reference to the Zodiac seriously, we find several symbols in his initial cryptogram that look like the symbol for Taurus the bull, which could identify his approximate birth date. He obviously liked astrology and might have viewed himself as fated by the stars. Those close to him would probably have heard him engage in knowledgeable discussions about astrological symbols and meanings.
Among the most engaging aspects of the crimes for him was to be able to taunt the authorities from a superior perspective and to watch the police make fools of themselves. This often indicates a person who feels uncertain about his intelligence, so to reassure himself, he plays games with others. The Zodiac needed to think he was smarter than even the best detectives, and he probably exaggerated the risks he took in order to affirm his smug sense of superiority. People who knew him would have been familiar with his arrogance, as well as his shortcomings and insecurity.
He used a lot of diversionary tactics, such as making threats that turned out not to be true, or posing cryptic mysteries. This is a form of what's called "duping delight." He's excited by duping others. The puzzles he presented probably meant nothing, but this man enjoyed knowing that a whole city full of people, as well as a number of law enforcement agencies, were at work on whatever code or clue he sent. That would have given him a thrill, knowing that the resolutions were merely dead-ends, and yet people would keep trying to find out what they meant. The closer they thought they were to identifying him, the more it would have amused him.
He enjoyed the control he exerted because he was in charge; he was running the investigation, more or less, as though he was the supervisor. He might have had pretensions of being a police officer, but for some reason been barred from this profession. This way, with these threats, he got to order them about. When he moved from the Vallejo area into San Francisco for his murders, he acquired a greater venue for control, along with the ability to spread the terror and feel more powerful. For him, it was all about that. He exerted control over his victims, and he did the same with anyone who was concerned about becoming a random victim.
He especially enjoyed controlling the newspapers and the police agencies of a town the size of San Francisco. He liked knowing they got into tiffs over territory and investigative squabbles. To his mind, that was more evidence of how stupid they were, and each day that went by without them catching him reinforced this opinion and sense of superiority. Every communication he sent fueled that fire.
 

Organized Homicide

http://psychautopsy.weebly.com/organized-vs-disorganized.html

Organized offenders are psychopathic and antisocial, irrational but sane. They are indifferent to fellow humans, irresponsible, and self-centered. They are manipulative, deliberative, and full of guile but outwardly amiable as long as it suits his objective. In other words, this type of offender could truly be a pillar of the community, the patron saint of child or spousal abuse prevention, and the neighborhood's most willing handyman. All the while, he is also the bogeyman who stalks his community's women, tortures them, and snuffs out their last breath. He is equally convincing in both roles and this is why the news reports always show the community astonishment in phrases like, "He was always such a nice guy." They are cunning and emotionless, which is how they can play both sides of the coin. When you have nothing emotional to invest in anyone, giving everyone exactly what they want takes nothing from you, but it can give you an advantage when you are trying to keep people from suspecting you are a compulsive murderer. This offender is extroverted, articulate, and highly narcissistic. He takes great care with his physical health and appearance. He will dress himself neatly whether in business or casual attire.There will always be a specific stressor in the offender's life that precipitates the beginning of his murderous career. These can be related to finances, employment, a marriage, or any close relationship. While there are events that will trigger the leap to murder, the fantasy is what fuels and builds up the desire to commit the crime. Offenders of this type will spend years, a decade or more, constructing their fantasy world. They use their crimes to hone these fantasies and improve upon them in order to heighten their level of self-gratification.This offender will perpetrate very deliberative crimes, thoroughly calculated and planned. Premeditation of these crimes will also typically include extensive stalking. He preys mostly on strangers so that he cannot be linked to their victims in any way. He will hunt far from work or home, but in an area he has surveilled and become intimately familiar with. The abduction and abuse of the victim will be perpetrated with as much precision and calculation as the predator has put into planning his clear escape. An organized sexual homicide will have multiple scenes: the location of initial contact or assault, the scene of death, and the body disposal site. This offender is socially adept and may con or persuade his victims into going with him willingly. He may pose as an authority figure, using a uniform that will disarm his victims such as that of a police officer. Victimology for an organized sexual homicide suggests a female or adolescent male. The victim will be single, employed, and live alone. The offender's risk for this type of crime is higher if committed outdoors or during the day. The victim of this crime is not known to the offender, but is chosen because she meets criteria specific to the killer's psychological construct. In multiple, linked homicides, the similarities in appearance of the victims will be obvious. For example, all of Ted Bundy's victims (except the last one) looked just like his ex-fiancee.This offender plans his murders, spends time targeting his victims, and displays control over the scene. He is methodical and orderly throughout all phases of the crime. The murders themselves are slow and sadistic for an experienced killer who is comfortable with his level of control over all factors. This type of offender is so in control of his surroundings that he can adapt to obstacles that occur during the commission of the crime in an outwardly calm manner. For example, the Zodiac killer was able to provide a dummy description of a dummy suspect when he came face to face with the police who were looking for him minutes after he'd shot a cab driver. Ed Kemper drove through a security gate at a college campus with two dying women in the car without raising any suspicion from the guards. These predators engage in staging to aid them in evading detection. The scene may be altered to appear careless or disorganized on purpose as a way to throw off the investigation. Secondary criminal activity may be staged to disguise the sexual homicide as some other type of murder.He takes care not to leave fingerprints, semen, or spent cartridges and shells. They make an effort to erase all prints and other potential evidence. Sometimes these perpetrators will scrub the victim down with bleach, along with the bathroom and kitchen, to destroy any trace he may have left. Some have been known to go to the extreme of removing all of their body hair and mutilating the tips of their fingers to avoid mishaps or carelessness at the scene. Weapons are brought to the scene by the perpetrator and leave the scene with him. He will have a "kit" consisting of various items like tape, chains, ropes, or chemicals. Restraints reflect a methodical approach, providing order for the perpetrator prior to, during, and after the crime. The scene will appear controlled and planned out. All finger- and footprints will be removed. Regardless of the ridiculous notions spouted off on television or in movies, these predators DO NOT want to be caught. EVER. They put so much effort into assuring they will outsmart the police because they all want to follow in the footsteps of Zodiac and Saucy Jack.This offender takes trophies to commemorate the success of his endeavor. They also serve as proof of his skill and control. These items will be used to help the perpetrator relive the fantasy he has acted out. He will conceal or dispose of the body in a location that is familiar to him, but not connected to the area where he lives or works. He will return to surveill the scenes and may inject himself into the investigation by being overly cooperative with law enforcement. Gary Ridgway, the Green River Killer, returned to the dump sites to have sex with the bodies of his victims over and over, until maggots invaded the body. This behavior serves a dual purpose: it keeps him apprised of the progress of the investigation while affording him the opportunity to relive the crime where it happened.

Comment From GuestGuest: ] how long have you been studying psychopaths, and has your views changed since you first began your study. 
Dr. Stephen Porter: 
I started studying psychopaths when I was working in a federal prison for my internship about twelve years ago. I thought I was having success providing weekly therapy to a psychopathic pedophile. However, his diary got confiscated after eleven months of therapy, and it turned out his fantasies were getting more and more sadistic and he wrote that he planned to murder children upon release. Not exactly a therapy success story! I started to research both the violent behaviour of psychopaths and their incredible ability to deceive and manipulate others. My views have changed over that time in the sense that I now believe that psychopaths are extremely rational and know the difference between right and wrong. Earlier, I felt that psychopaths were impulsive and that somehow their bizarre behaviour was beyond their choice. Our research has challenged that idea. 
Comment From FredFred: ] What signs would you expect to see from a close contact which may indicate pschopathic tendencies? 
 Dr. Stephen Porter: 
I'm not sure if by "close contact" you mean a family member or acquaintance/work colleague. But either way, typically the person will come across as highly likeable and charming, even charismatic. However, this charm is superficial in the sense that it is all part of an acting job, intended to manipulate the other person. In other words, the individual's behaviour will ultimately contradict the friendly, charming mask. You will see a pattern of persistent lying and deception (from a young age) including false promises, a "gift of gab", callous behaviour, including taking advantage of and conning others, a sense of superiority, stepping on others to get ahead, promiscuous sexual behaviour, and an inability to form anything more than superficial bonds with friends or partners. Often, such individuals are described in a Jekyll and Hyde way, such as "he was so likeable and friendly, a real class clown but then I got involved with him and found out the truth too late." 
Comment From Elizabeth: ] As psychopaths know right from wrong, what causes them to commit violent crimes, and what justifications do they give for their behaviour?  
Dr. Stephen Porter: 
Great question and one we have been researching for some time. Psychopaths in my view do know right from wrong in the "cognitive" or rational sense, and even do as well on moral-reasoning tasks in the lab setting as the rest of us. A better question might be why don't most people NOT act on their immoral or even violent impulses. All humans have sexual, violent, and antisocial thoughts and impulses that they choose not to act upon because of our "conscience". We have empathy for others and we know we could not live with ourselves if we acted on the dark thought. Psychopaths don't have to worry about a conscience to stop them from doing violent crimes. Research suggests that some of their main motivations include calculated revenge, thrill-seeking and sex, pure greed, and do intimidate and gain power. Many of the violent psychopaths we have studied were inspired purely by getting a thrill. For example, our research shows that the vast majority of sex offenders who cross the line from children to adults or vice versa are psychopaths. When asked about this pattern, one fellow I assessed told me he simply got bored with one victim type and then would move to another type.

The DNA of 33 women was found on Robert Picton's farm, but dozens of women are still unaccounted for.

 
Another home that Henning co-owned with his father in 108 Mile Ranch along a section of the Cariboo Highway now dubbed "The Highway of Tears".  Henning co-owned the home sometime from the early to mid 70's and took over ownership in the mid 90's.  Map shows how bodies began to circle an area around his home during that time.

 

The Impact
The ability to bring awareness to this story and the abundance of circumstantial evidence that points Henning to being the Zodiac Killer as well as the BC Serial Killer who has been claiming victims in British Columbia, Canada for the past 40 years.  This awareness could in turn warrant investigation through the US and Canadian authorities which may result in the prosecution of the offender.
The ability to possibly solve the identity of the Zodiac Killer, one of the most infamous serial killers in World History.  The ability to possibly solve the identity of the BC serial killer who is still at large.  It is suspected by the police that there were 3 serial killers involved in BC's missing women.  One suspect has since passed away and Robert Pickton has been incarcerated since he was arrested in 2002 and subsequently sentenced to life in prison, leaving one suspect still at large during a time when women continued to disappear.  My theory presented in my book will show how Henning fits the profile and how more circumstantial evidence could point to him being the worst serial killer in Canadian History.
At minimum we revive the legend of Zodaic with refreshing new material and a suspect who some around the world have claimed for themself is indeed the Zodiac Killer.  Through the stats feature on my blog I am able to track traffic sources back to various message boards and discussions around the world where some believe that my material is more compelling than any other ever presented..... and I have only presented the tip of the iceberg in the stories on my blog.  There is much more to this amazing story that will be sure to capture the reader from start to finish and create a stir across the entire planet as to whether this man is indeed the Zodiac Killer who continued to evolve and kill North of the Canada/US Border.

"Zodiac Killer North", Book Funding - $3,000 
 
BC's long and winding highways (and logging roads), along dense forests create many vanishing points.

 
Whether the man who abused my child is or is not the Zodiac Killer, I absolutely believe with every fiber of my being that he is a killer here in British Columbia, Canada responsible for dozens if not into the hundreds of missing women over the past 40 years.  The compelling circumstantial evidence that points this man to being the Zodiac Killer may be only coincidental, however it is strong enough for me name the BC Killer in perhpas only a metaphorical sense, "Zodiac Killer North", whilst leaving speculation open as to whether Zodiac simply continued his killing spree just North of the Canada/US border.  There is much more circumstantial evidence to be presented in my book than is posted on my blog.
I require $3,000 to complete my book.  These funds are allocated to completing, formating and editing the manuscript as well as covering any associated fees for mailing hard copies of manuscripts to agents and publishers for review.  I am personally donating 100% of my time into continued research, documentation, completion of draft material, public awareness and pre-marketing so that when the manuscript is finished I am fully prepared to seek publishing with an audience already in place.

I require $2000 for website development, SEO and technical training so that I can maintain my own website for producing new issues and continue with SEO.

Will accept full or partial donations and/or quotations for services in the following:
 

Handwriting Expert (donated)

What You Get
An opportunity to create History!

story:
Buried History (Campaign Video)

"The past never dies." Zita Valanguerra Spinelli, Marchesa of Scalea (1794-1882)

HISTORY is full of ghosts, particularly in Sicily where the truth is often buried alive. This book campaign, organized by Guernica Editions and sponsored by the Italian Cultural Foundation at Casa Belvedere, exhumes a forgotten heritage and challenges official narratives about the past.

Before reading further, however, watch:

  • "Trinàcria: The Past Never Dies."

This video will introduce you to our author and his characters, while the sections below will background our campaign and detail fundraising.

The photograph on the right, Marco Lanza's La Cripta dei Cappuccini, is available as a poster. For other donation gifts, browse our gallery catalog.

 

Background

Guernica Editions, an independent press based in Toronto, Ontario, wishes to publish Trinàcria: A Tale of Bourbon Sicily. Like Giuseppe Tomasi di Lampedusa’s The Leopard, Federico De Roberto’s The Viceroys, and Susan Sontag’s The Volcano Lover, this historical novel deals with the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies in the decades leading up to the Italian Revolution.

Dedicated to promoting new works of global literature and shattering old stereotypes, Guernica considers Trinàcria “a timely book.” Last year’s Sesquicentennial of the Risorgimento stirred controversy in Italy and abroad. Did unification benefit or ruin the Mezzogiorno, the ancestral region of most Italian immigrants?

Publishing Trinàcria, Guernica believes, "could contribute significantly" to the ongoing reassessment of the Italian Revolution on both sides of the Atlantic. By implication, however, the book also examines the limitations of modern commercial democracies and warns about the dangers of nation-building in the developing world.

 

Fundraising

Because Guernica’s government funding does not extend to non-Canadian authors, the Italian Cultural Foundation at Casa Belvedere is sponsoring this fundraiser. Such patronage reflects Casa Belvedere's ongoing mission "to preserve and promote an appreciation of Italian language, arts, literature, history, fashion, cuisine, and commerce."   

This campaign intends to raise a minimum of $5,000 between now and December 13. This sum will cover the book's editing, design, production, and distribution. Donations made after we meet this goal will pay for campaign costs, such as printing, postage, promotional expenses, and online site fees. Either way, your money will be put to good use.

Contributors can rely on the sterling reputation of our fundraising consultant Roberto Ragone. With help from Debra Santagelo, president of Sicilian Connections, he brought together Casa Belvedere and Guernica Editions on this international literary project.

Roberto's motto is: "Transforming Vision to Value." As former executive director of the New York’s Lower East Side Business Improvement District, Roberto served as marketing director for the Ciao America Film Project and president and publicist for FIERI International, an organization of college students and young professionals interested in celebrating and promoting Italian culture. To learn more about Roberto and his background, review his LinkedIn profile at:

  • http://www.linkedin.com/profile/ragone

 

Synopsis of Novel

Set in 18th- and 19th-century Palermo, Naples, and London, Trinàcria: A Tale of Bourbon Sicily revolves around the Marchesa of Scalea, Zita Valanguerra Spinelli, notorious beauty, ferocious wit, secret murderer, and reluctant businesswoman, whose turbulent life mirrors her world’s rocky transition from feudalism to capitalism.

Shortly after the centennial of Garibaldi’s conquest, a Hollywood film crew invades Palermo to shoot an epic about the Italian Revolution. Researching the past, the director visits the Capuchin Monastery, whose catacombs contain over eight thousand mummies. Preserved among these is Marchesa Spinelli, dead for eighty years but still haunted by memories. Posthumously, she recalls her complicated relationships with Don Alfonso, her scientist father; Benjamin Ingham, a British wine merchant and an honorary Sicilian baron, whom the Marchesa failed to marry; Regina, her patriotic and rebellious granddaughter, who idolizes Verdi and Garibaldi; and Giacomo Leopardi, the doomed Romantic poet.

Drawing on history and family legend, Trinàcria presents a tale of progress and reaction, irony and paradox, in which the splendors of Caserta must yield to the wonders of the Crystal Palace. Both intimate and sweeping, this work questions the price of pride and the cost of prosperity and contrasts illusions of grandeur and happiness with the pitiless truth that kills all hope and desire. As readers will learn, this is the fatal spell of Sicily—an island of loss and change—where death alone is eternal.

 

A Taste of Trinàcria

Sicilian pastry expresses the island's Baroque imagination. For generations, master bakers have molded fruit out of marzipan and knights out of sugar. This tradition continues at Villabate-Alba Pasticceria and Bakery in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn.

The Alaimo family, whose ancestral town of Villabate is the novel's main setting, still make traditional cannoli and cassata. During November, the Month of the Dead, however, they also bake ossi di morti, almond cookies resembling human bones.

In the same spirit, Guernica Editions serves you "Eternal Death." Orginally published in Feile-Festa; The Literary Arts Journal of the Mediterranean Celtic Cultural Association, this excerpt from Trinàcria introduces the ghost of the Marchesa of Scalea. "The Latest Invasion," the book's prologue, is posted in our gallery. A $25 donation buys a PDF of the entire novel.

 

Advanced Praise

Read what critics have to say about Trinàcria:

“History,” T. S. Eliot observed, “has many cunning passages, contrived corridors.” Anthony Di Renzo’s novella Trinàcria: A Tale of Bourbon Sicily demonstrates how cunningly we all contrive to find in history only the lessons we want to. The book’s narrator, to our initial surprise, is the mummified corpse of Zita Valanguerra Spinelli, Marchesa of Scalea (1794-1882), who had adopted the nom de plume of Trinàcria, an ancient name for Sicily. But soon the voice of this long-dead wit and salonnière—arrogant, erudite, and vengeful—grows as familiar to us as the thousand little lies we tell ourselves each day.

Donna Zita represents Di Renzo’s spirited rejoinder to Giuseppe Tomasi di Lampedusa’s classic novel Il Gattopardo (The Leopard), a nostalgic portrayal of old aristocratic Sicily and its privileged world, swept away by Garibaldi’s conquest. Less objective than Lampedusa’s Prince Fabrizio Corbera, Marchesa Spinelli blames the commercial and materialistic forces unleashed by Sicily’s unification with the new kingdom of Italy for ushering in a vapid culture in which the presiding deity is money. But more “things” will never make people better: “We aristocrats have plenty of things,” Donna Zita remarks, “and we are proud and vicious.”

Di Renzo’s writing is vivid and brimful of sardonic humor. He specializes in crisp evocations of outdoor scenes, such as the bustling streets of Naples or the unforgettably cruel festival of the Cuccagna; but the main attraction is the marchesa herself, a force of nature as powerful and inexorable as the Sicilian sun in July.

~Peter D'Epiro and Mary Desmond Pinkowish, authors of Sprezzatura: 50 Ways Italian Genius Shaped the World

“The past never dies,” says Zita Valanguerra Spinelli, Marchesa of Scalea, the narrator and protagonist of Trinàcria: A Tale of Bourbon Sicily. Neither does the eternal appeal of Sicily. The Italian American writer Anthony Di Renzo has breathed new life into the glorious tradition of the Sicilian historical novel.

This fascinating book dialogues with literature, cinema, and the figurative arts. Di Renzo not only evokes the history of the Bourbons and the Risorgimento but also captures Sicily’s aura as a “paper island,” an imaginative world created by Italy’s most important modern writers. His novel will remind readers of De Roberto's The Viceroys and Tomasi di Lampedusa’s The Leopard, two different and perhaps even opposite works. The first seems to have inspired Di Renzo’s love for the surreal and grotesque, the second his lyricism and elegiac melancholy.

Donna Zita is a fascinating character. She is romantic and enlightened, rebellious and ambitious, beautiful and mysterious. Her nickname Trinacrìa, one of Sicily’s most ancient names, shows her complete identification with this paradoxical island: wild but cultured, timeless but ephemeral, sparkling but bleak. For Zita, as for Sicily, the present is transient, while the past is eternal. Sicily here is simultaneously myth and reality. While the novel’s historical data is accurate and authentic, this book appeals to the eye more than the mind. From the opening scene in which a Hollywood crew prepares to shoot an epic about Garibaldi's Thousand in Palermo, the reader is carried away by a montage of beautiful images. Through sheer witchcraft, Anthony Di Renzo recreates the timeless spell of the Medusa.

~Margherita Ganeri, author of The Italian Historical Novel

Anthony Di Renzo’s Trinàcria peels away layers of 19th-century Sicilian history in a way that academic and popular studies of this period cannot. The novel provides an intimate perspective on sweeping public events. Di Renzo tells the story of Zita Valanguerra Spinelli, Marchesa of Scalea, who is a composite of two historical figures:  Antonia Vassallo, Princess of Bellaprima, and Alessandra Spadafora, Duchess of Santa Rosalia. During her long life, Donna Zita meets kings and queens, great composers, poets, and foreign entrepreneurs seeking to make their fortunes off her island's bounty.  Di Renzo’s sardonic depiction of the Marchesa's deeply felt cynicism often kicks the modern reader in the gut: the brutality of husbands toward wives; the cruelty of fathers toward children; the impact of a woman's revenge and of her unyielding, unforgiving pride; above all, the lost promise of Italy's Unification to Sicilians This finely crafted novel glitters with polished metaphors and sparking epigrams. It is a marvelous work in the tradition of Dacia Maraini's The Silent Duchess.

~John Keahey, author of Seeking Sicily

A triumph of wit and eloquence, Anthony Di Renzo’s Trinàcria: A Tale of Bourbon Sicily displays a thorough knowledge of Italian culture, weaving fascinating historical material with astute commentaries about Italian life, ancient and modern. Di Renzo creates unforgettable scenes sometimes operatic in their intensity.  His confident, beguiling style will remind readers of Giuseppe Tomasi di Lampedusa’s in The Leopard and of Salman Rushdie’s at his very best.  Like these authors, Di Renzo adroitly dips in and out of magical realism, but never lets technique interfere with fast plotting and vivid characterization.  The novel’s brilliant, bedraggled narrator, the Marchesa of Scalea (nicknamed Trinàcria, after the three-legged symbol of Sicily), is always lively, even when speaking from her tomb, full of wisdom, caustic humor and eccentric charm.  Her tragicomic story makes Trinàcria an enormously satisfying historical novel.

~Edward Hower, author of The New Life Hotel and Storms of May

What a great read this novel is, better than a trip to Sicily!  Full of shock and delight, Trinàcria forms a fascinating epic about Bourbon Palermo on the eve of disaster.  In the book's title character, the Marchesa of Scalea, Anthony Di Renzo creates a woman who demonstrates the folly and passion of living life defiantly on the brink.  Few writers are better at showing the intimate, sometimes comic connections between the past and the present, between the old world and the new. If you love drama and discovery, you will enjoy Trinàcria: A Tale of Bourbon Sicily.

~Jeanne Mackin, author of The Sweet By and By and Dreams of Empire

Trinàcria: A Tale of Bourbon Sicily is a completely original look at a long-maligned and misunderstood island—a part of and yet always apart from the modern political construct of Italy. In a work rich with history, Anthony Di Renzo takes the reader into Sicily’s pre-unification past by having the mummified dead of Palermo’s Capuchin catacombs confront a film crew from Italy’s dolce vita era. This fascinating metaphysical and psychological landscape is replete with Redshirts, petty nobility, studio hacks, and two centuries of bitter Sicilian wisdom. "We all have skeletons in the closet," says the Marchesa of Scalea, the novel’s narrator and protagonist. “If they must rattle, they may as well dance.” And dance they do in a macabre but spirited tarantella.

~Paul Paolicelli, author of Dances with Luigi and Under the Southern Sun

Most historical fiction paints the past in flattering oils. Trinàcria: A Tale of Bourbon Sicily is etched in acid. Goya could have created this novel’s caustic characters, particularly its protagonist and narrator, Zita Valanguerra Spinelli, the baleful Marchesa of Scalea, whose crest is modeled after the three-legged gorgon of Sicily. Donna Zita recounts her life from a crypt in Palermo’s Capuchin Catacombs. Outrage over lost privilege has given her a posthumous case of acid reflux. But as the Marchesa relives past violations—her land scorched to dust by the pitiless Sicilian sun; her carriage hacked to pieces by Garibaldi’s Red Shits; her crest and nom de plume Trinàcria, the ancient name of Sicily, turned into a label for cheap, mass-produced vinegar—readers learn to sympathize with this spiteful banshee.

Anthony Di Renzo’s masterful, richly textured and layered narrative never hesitates to challenge its own discourse of storytelling, to question the ways craft transforms history into fiction.  But it also poses an ethical challenge. Like the Marchesa, the author confronts our complacency and demands that we examine our own vanities, political hubris, and fragility. Will we take responsibility for our individual and collective histories or float into oblivion, thinking life was all a trick? This spellbinding narrative leaves us with no answers, only the lingering scent of broom.

~Shona Ramaya, author of Flute, Beloved Mother, Queen of Night, and Operation Monsoon

 

Features and Articles

Features and articles about Trinàcria have appeared in the following periodicals:

America Oggi:"Letteratura: La Trinàcria del Professore Di Renzo" (August 26, 2012)

Best of Sicily Blog:"Anthony Di Renzo's Trinàcria Casts a Sober Glance Toward Italian Unification" (September 3, 2012)

i-Italy: "Trinàcria by Anthony Di Renzo" (September 25, 2012)

Italiansrus.com: A Guide to Italy and Italian Culture: "A Novel Approach to Two Sicilies" (November 26, 2012)

Italian Voice:"Casa Belvedere Sponsors Historical Novel about Sicily" (August 23, 2012) 

Life in a New World:

  • "Anthony Di Renzo: Postmodern Lessons from the Italian Diaspora" (November 29, 2013)
  • "Q&A with Trinàcria’s Author Anthony Di Renzo" (November 28, 2012)
  • "Podcast Interview with Roberto Ragone on His Latest Project Trinàcria: A Tale of Bourbon Sicily” (November 24, 2012)

Magna Grece Magazine:

  • "Villabate Pastry Shop Advances Historical Novel Set in Sicilian Hometown" (March 27, 2013)
  • "Roberto Ragone's Birthday Celebration Fundraiser" (November 9, 2012)
  • "An Interview with Anthony Di Renzo" (October 7, 2012)
  • "Pledge Drive Promotes Historical Novel about Sicily" (August 21, 2012)

New Jersey Newsroom:"Historical Novel about Sicily Breaks Stereotypes" (August 18, 2012)

Sicilian Connections:

  • "Villabate Pastry Shop Advances Historical Novel Set in Sicilian Hometown" (March 27, 2013)
  • "Canadian Publisher Promotes Historical Novel Challenging Italian Unification" (November 14, 2012)
  • "British Entrepreneur Advances Historical Novel with Anglo-Sicilian Theme" (November 9, 2012)
  • "New York Arts Consultant Builds 'Cultural Capital' Within Italian American Community" (October, 10  2012)
  • "Casa Belvedere Sponsors Historical Novel about Sicily: Foundation Continues Exploration of Italian National Identity through Literary Project" (September 4, 2012)

Times of Sicily:

  • "British Entrepreneur Advances Historical Novel with Anglo-Sicilian Theme" (November 8, 2012)
  • "The Past Never Dies - Though God Knows it Tries: An Interview with Anthony Di Renzo" (October 6, 2012)
  • "New York Arts Consultant Builds 'Cultural Capital' Within Italian American Community" (September 30, 2012)
  • "Casa Belvedere Sponsors Historical Novel about Sicily" (August 17, 2012)

Trinacria News:"Casa Belvedere Sponsorizza i Romanzi Storici sulla Sicilia" (September 28, 2012) 

 

About the Author

A fugitive from advertising, Anthony Di Renzo teaches writing and Italian American history at Ithaca College and has appeared in Alimentum, Il Caffé, Cottonwood Magazine, Essays & Fictions, Feile-Festa, The Normal School, River Styx, Syracuse Scholar, and Voices in Italian Americana. His most recent book Bitter Greens: Essays on Food, Politics, and Ethnicity from the Imperial Kitchen (State University of New York Press, 2010) was praised by Gastonomica: The Journal of Food and Culture.

On a more personal note, Di Renzo on his mother's side descends from Spanish nobility, who settled in Bagheria, Sicily in the early 18th century. He now lives near the West End, Ithaca, New York's former Italian neighborhood, "an Old World man in a New Age town." Trinàcria will be his first published novel.

For more information about the author and his work, visit:

  • http://faculty.ithaca.edu/direnzo

 

Donations, Gifts, and Orders

“Charity," said the 18th-century Neapolitan economist Ferdinando Galiani, "ennobles the giver and obligates the recipient. The former is noble while the latter is common."

By contributing to this campaign, you will earn a place in our Golden Book of Donors. Based on the aristocratic ranks of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies, these donor levels entitle you to various gifts. These items are displayed in our gallery catalog.

After pledging money at or near a specific donor level, select your item(s) from the catalog and contact me at the above website. Specify your item(s) and provide a mailing address so I can place your order with the Ithaca College Print Shop. Please allow three to four weeks for process and delivery.

 

Outstanding Contributors

The following individuals, organizations, or businesses have donated $250 or more in funds or in-kind gifts:

  • Paul Ahlers (NPR)
  • Best of Sicily
  • The Chechile Family (Caly Services: Janitorial and Restaurant Supplies)
  • Maria Glockner (JPMorgan Chase)
  • The Mediterranean Celtic Cultural Association (MCCA)
  • Mark E. Miller (Miller Manhattan Property Group)
  • Kameron Mohammed (Twangdillo)
  • New York City's Sicilian Food, Wine & Travel Group
  • Pallante Center for Italian Research (PCIR)
  • Sicilian Connections
  • Sicilian Film Festival (SFF)
  • Umberto's Clam House
  • Villabate-Alba Pasticerria and Bakery
  • Emanuele Viscuso

 

Our Sponsor

This book campaign is made possible by the Italian Cultural Foundation at Casa Belevedere. A stately Italianate villa with a breathtaking view of the Verrazano Bridge, Casa Belvedere hosts Italian language, culinary, art, and music classes, as well as galas, fashion shows, wine tastings, exhibits, and symposiums focused on Italian themes.

These events open a window to the past.

Last year, the foundation capped its commemoration of the Sesquicentennial of the Risorgimento with a public debate on Italian Unification. Moderated by Cavaliere Vincenzo Marra, this lively exchange between Pino Aprile, author of Terroni (Piemme 2010), and Lorenzo del Boca, author of Polentoni (Piemme 2011) touched upon the often painful historical and political issues discussed in Trinàcria. Click the link below to see this debate:

  • The Great Debate: Terroni versus Polentoni (November 8, 2011)

Guernica Editions is grateful for Casa Belvedere's support and hopes this novel will contribute to its mission. Mille grazie to founder and president Gina Biancardi and executive director Louis Calvelli!

Posthumously, she recalls her complicated relationships with Don Alfonso, her scientist father; Benjamin Ingham, a British wine merchant and an honorary Sicilian baron, whom the Marchesa failed to marry; Regina, her patriotic and rebellious granddaughter, who idolizes Verdi and Garibaldi; and Giacomo Leopardi, the doomed Romantic poet.
